title: Dale Dike Reservoir Walking Route

images.title: Terry Robinson / View from Thornseat Lodge across Dale Dike Reservoir
images.caption: View from Thornseat Lodge across Dale Dike Reservoir. Andrew Wood Tree Plantation and Loftshaw Workings can be seen in the distance

images.title: Neil Theasby / View towards Dale Dyke Reservoir from the south west.
images.caption: View towards Dale Dike Reservoir from the south west. The source of the fatal Sheffield Flood of 1864.

images.title: Dave Taylor / Dale Dyke Memorial plaque
images.caption: Plaque in memory of the flood disaster victims of 1864. The original reservoir embankment collapsed flooding the Loxley and Don Valleys.

images.title: Paul Glover / Pump house
images.caption: Pump house. Controls for the dam at Dale dike reservoir are inside this small building hidden in the woods.

images.title: Paul Glover / Lichen loves the damp
images.caption: An old barn built of gritstone above Dale Dike reservoir.

images.title: Across the fields by dave hudson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A view of the countryside and woodlands you can see to the west of the reservoir.

images.title: Between Strines and Dale Dyke Reservoirs by Graham Hogg, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The view between Strines and Dale Dyke Reservoirs

description: This pretty reservoir near Sheffield has waterside paths to follow around the perimeter. There is also the opportunity to climb into the woodlands and countryside around the reservoir. The circuit runs for about 4 miles through Bradfield Dale and along the adjacent Strines Reservoir . Dale Dike is part of series of reservoirs in the area. You can also visit Damflask Reservoir and Agden Reservoir for more good walking trails and beautiful Peak District scenery. You can also climb west to Derwent Edge and Back Tor for great views back down to the surrounding reservoirs.
